question.text: In a population of an area, natality was equal to mortality for a given time period. However, the population density of the population increased. Which of the following may be the reason for the increase?

options.text: Number of immigrants = number of emigrants
Number of immigrants <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo><</mo></math> Number of emigrants

solution.text:
Natality and immigration contribute to an increase in population density, whereas mortality and emigration tend to decrease the size.

The density of a population (N) at time t can be expressed after a period of time (t + 1) as: 

N(t+1) = Nt + [ (B + I) - (D + E) ]

where B denotes the number of births,  I denotes the number of immigrants, D is the number of deaths and E is the number of emigrants.

If B = D, and N(t+1) > Nt, then I > E.
